publications.name: Fast Distribtued Selection with Graphics Processing Units
publications.publisher: IEEE Open Journal of the Computer Society, Under Review
publications.summary: We introduce two completely parallel algorithms for exactly solving the distributed multiple order statistic problem. The main algorithm, DIBMS, keeps communication costs proportional to the number of order statistics with minimal communication of actual data. Moreover, the work done at the remote nodes is fully parallelized on graphics processing units.

researches.name: Grinnell College, advised by Professor Jeffrey Blanchard
researches.position: Fast Distributed Selection with Graphics Processing Units
researches.summary: Extracting multiple order statistics from a huge, distributed data set provides important information about the distribution of the values in the full set of data. We proposed an algorithm, DistributedIterativeBucketMultiSelect, or DIBMS, which selects the percentile from a data set of 268 million values distributed at eight locations in less than a quarter of a second.

researches.name: Grinnell College, advised by Professor Charlie Curtsinger
researches.position: Riker: Always-Correct and Fast Incremental Builds
researches.summary: Riker is a forward build system that guarantees fast, correct builds. Riker builds are easy to specify; in many cases a single command such as gcc *.c suffices. From these simple specifications, Riker automatically discovers fast incremental rebuild opportunities.
